title: Cushing Disease Due to ACTH-Secreting Pituitary Adenoma
setup_script: A 35-year-old woman has progressive weight gain, facial rounding, purple striae, and hypertension. Labs show elevated 24-hour urinary cortisol and failure to suppress on low-dose dexamethasone test. ACTH level is elevated. Pituitary MRI reveals a 6 mm microadenoma.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Discuss differential for hypercortisolism: Cushing disease, ectopic ACTH, adrenal adenoma/carcinoma.
Order confirmatory tests: midnight salivary cortisol, high-dose dexamethasone suppression, CRH stimulation to differentiate sources.
Interpret results consistent with pituitary ACTH secretion; plan for transsphenoidal pituitary surgery.
Coordinate with neurosurgery and endocrinology; obtain preoperative ophthalmology exam and cortisol control with ketoconazole/mifepristone if severe.
Discuss surgical risks: CSF leak, hypopituitarism, diabetes insipidus; obtain informed consent.
Perform transsphenoidal resection of microadenoma; confirm histology of corticotroph tumor.
Monitor postoperative cortisol; treat adrenal insufficiency with stress dosing and taper accordingly.
Assess for postoperative complications: visual changes, diabetes insipidus, infection; manage promptly.
Follow up with endocrinology for hormone replacement (thyroid, adrenal, gonadal) if hypopituitarism occurs.
If residual or recurrent tumor, consider repeat surgery, radiation, or medical therapy (pasireotide, cabergoline).
Educate patient on symptoms of adrenal insufficiency and necessity for medical alert identification.
Arrange long-term surveillance with cortisol levels and MRI to detect recurrence.

critical_decision_points: Differentiating causes of Cushing syndrome and confirming pituitary source.
Planning and coordinating transsphenoidal surgery with multidisciplinary team.
Managing perioperative adrenal insufficiency and stress dosing.
Long-term surveillance for recurrence and management of hypopituitarism.
